title: I paid for my mothers funeral expenses before her life insurance money came in.can i get the money back like a creditor?
question: my sisters are trying to get money from the life insurance money my mom left me.I paid out of pocket all the funeral costs up front in full. The written will stipulates that the sister get 5,000 each there are 4 of them. after the house was sold. but the house is soo upside down it is worth less then 100,000 dollars. so they want the oney in her acct. 2,000 and the vehicals worth together 5,000 dollars. can i ask for the funeral costs to be paid before they do and get the money back. they are sueing me but they paid for nothing and didn't care about her.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Wills and estates,Estates,Life insurance and estate planning,Taxes and estate planning,Wills,Contesting a will,Executor of will,Probate,State, local, and municipal law,Tax law
answers:
If you were the beneficiary of the life insurance policy, that money is yours. And under California law the funeral expenses are a "priority" claim that is paid before the beneficiaries receive anything. You need to file a Creditor's Claim in the probate proceeding. You don't have much time in which to do that ... only 4 months from the date that the executor is appointed and "letters testamentary" are issued.

If you are being sued, you need to have an attorney representing you. Hopefully that attorney knows probate law and procedure and should be able to advise you regarding your claim.

The information you obtain at this site is not, nor is it intended to be, legal advice. You should consult an attorney for individual advice regarding your own situation.

The objective of probate is to insure that all of the debts of the estate are paid first. Does the will address the payment priority and specifically the payment of funeral expenses? Has a petition been filed for probate. Your facts are insufficient to answer your question. You should seek the counsel of a local probate attorney.

It is difficult to tell from your post the specific nature of the life insurance proceeds and to whom they are payable.

As for the funeral expenses, local law will determine how expenses are paid from a decedent's estate. Funeral expenses typically carry a high priority. Your payment of the proceeds may be treated as a loan to the estate for which you should be reimbursed. If you are also a beneficiary of the estate, that may reduce the amount that you will receive.

I would recommend that you contact a local attorney who is familiar with probate proceeds and will contests.
